solution: Group IIA: CdS is yellow and insoluble in yellow ammonium sulphide; As/Sb/Sn sulphides are soluble (Group IIB).

question_text: Which cations form sulphides soluble in yellow ammonium sulphide? 1. As³⁺, 2. Sb³⁺, 3. Sn²⁺ / Sn⁴⁺, 4. Cu²⁺.
hint: These belong to the 'Subgroup IIB' or the arsenic group.
solution: Group IIB: As₂S₃, Sb₂S₃, SnS/SnS₂ dissolve forming thio-complexes; CuS is insoluble.

question_text: From a mixture of Group IIA cations, you obtain a black ppt of sulphides (HgS, PbS, CuS, Bi₂S₃, CdS). After dissolving ppt in hot dilute HNO₃ and filtering, the insoluble residue is:
hint: Only the sulfide of Mercury(II) is so insoluble that it resists dissolution by hot nitric acid.
solution: HgS is not dissolved by hot dilute HNO₃; others form soluble nitrates.

question_text: Which reactions are used to confirm Pb²⁺? 1. Yellow ppt of PbI₂, 2. Yellow ppt of PbCrO₄, 3. White ppt of PbSO₄ (with dil. H₂SO₄), 4. Solubility of PbSO₄ in hot ammonium acetate.
hint: Lead is confirmed through the formation of colored halides and chromates after selective separation.
solution: All four are standard lead confirmatory tests.

question_text: A Group I ppt dissolves in NH₄OH, forming a clear solution. On acidifying, white ppt reappears. The cation is:
hint: Formation of a soluble ammine complex is unique to Silver among the Group I chlorides.
solution: AgCl dissolves in NH₃ as [Ag(NH₃)₂]⁺ and re-precipitates as AgCl on acidification.

question_text: For Hg₂²⁺ (Group I), which observations are correct? 1. With HCl: white Hg₂Cl₂ ppt, 2. With NH₄OH: black Hg + HgNH₂Cl, 3. With KI: red HgI₂, soluble in excess KI, 4. With Cu foil: black coating of Hg.
hint: Mercury(I) ions show complex redox chemistry including disproportionation and replacement by copper.
solution: All four are standard Hg(I) reactions.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with Group I reagent, but with H₂S in acid, a black ppt forms which is insoluble in hot dil. H₂SO₄ and dil. HNO₃. It dissolves in aqua regia to give solution forming white ppt with SnCl₂ (first silky white, then black). The cation is:
hint: The use of aqua regia and SnCl₂ points directly to the confirmation of Mercury(II).
solution: HgS (Group IIA) is only dissolved by aqua regia, and SnCl₂ gives Hg₂Cl₂ (white) then Hg (black).

question_text: Which cation–flame colour pairs are correct? 1. Li⁺ – crimson red, 2. Na⁺ – golden yellow, 3. K⁺ – lilac, 4. Ba²⁺ – apple green.
hint: These are the standard Bunsen flame emissions for common s-block metal cations.
solution: All listed flame colours match the table.

question_text: A salt shows bluish-green flame and gives deep blue solution with excess NH₄OH. The cation is:
hint: The blue solution complex [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ is a very well-known identification feature.
solution: Cu²⁺: flame bluish-green; [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ is deep blue.

question_text: For Al³⁺ confirmatory tests: 1. White gelatinous Al(OH)₃ ppt in Group III, 2. Al(OH)₃ dissolves in excess NaOH giving aluminate, 3. Cobalt nitrate + ignition on charcoal gives blue mass, 4. Al(OH)₃ gives blood-red colour with KSCN.
hint: Thiocyanate is used for iron, whereas aluminum is confirmed via its amphoterism and Thenard's blue test.
solution: 4 is for Fe³⁺; 1–3 are Al³⁺ tests.

question_text: A Group III ppt is green. After fusion with KNO₃ + Na₂CO₃, extract with water gives yellow Na₂CrO₄ solution. With Pb(OAc)₂, a yellow ppt appears. The cation is:
hint: Conversion of green hydroxide to yellow chromate confirms the presence of this transition metal.
solution: Cr(OH)₃ green; on fusion forms chromate; PbCrO₄ yellow ppt.

question_text: Which are distinctive tests for Fe³⁺? 1. Reddish-brown Fe(OH)₃ ppt (Group III), 2. Prussian blue with K₄[Fe(CN)₆], 3. Blood-red complex with KSCN, 4. Green solution with NaOH.
hint: Iron(III) salts do not form green solutions with alkali; they precipitate as rust-colored hydroxides.
solution: 4 corresponds to Fe²⁺ (Fe(OH)₂ green).

question_text: A salt solution gives gelatinous white ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl (Group III). The ppt dissolves in excess NaOH, re-precipitates on addition of NH₄Cl and heating. The cation is:
hint: This sequence utilizes the amphoteric nature of Aluminum and its precipitation at neutral pH.
solution: Typical Al(OH)₃ amphoteric behaviour.

question_text: Which reactions describe Zn²⁺ correctly? 1. Group IV: ZnS white ppt with H₂S in ammoniacal medium, 2. Zn(OH)₂ amphoteric; dissolves in excess NaOH, 3. With K₄[Fe(CN)₆]: white/bluish white ppt, 4. Flame test shows intense characteristic colour.
hint: Zinc lacks a distinctive Bunsen flame color used in standard qualitative analysis.
solution: Zn²⁺ has no distinctive flame colour.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt in Group I–III. In Group IV, with NH₄Cl + NH₄OH + H₂S, a white ppt forms. On adding dil. HCl, ppt dissolves giving a solution that with Na₂HPO₄ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH gives no ppt. The cation is:
hint: The only white sulfide in Group IV is Zinc Sulfide.
solution: ZnS white; Zn²⁺ does not give MgNH₄PO₄ ppt (specific for Mg²⁺).

question_text: Which statements about Mn²⁺ in qualitative analysis are correct? 1. MnS buff or light pink in Group IV, 2. Mn(OH)₂ white, turning brown on oxidation, 3. Mn²⁺ → permanganate with NaBiO₃/HNO₃, 4. Mn²⁺ gives intense flame colour.
hint: Manganese salts are identified by their sulfide color and powerful oxidation to permanganate.
solution: Mn has no strong flame test; 1–3 are correct.

question_text: A salt solution gives black ppt with NH₄Cl + NH₄OH + H₂S (Group IV). The ppt dissolves in aqua regia; on treatment with KNO₂ + CH₃COOH + K⁺ (excess), a yellow ppt appears. The cation is:
hint: Formation of the yellow cobaltinitrite complex confirms the presence of Cobalt.
solution: CoS (black); Co²⁺ → K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] yellow ppt with KNO₂ + CH₃COOH.

question_text: Standard confirmatory tests for Ni²⁺: 1. Red ppt with DMG in basic medium, 2. Green solution with excess NH₄OH, 3. Black NiS in Group IV, 4. Grey bead in borax bead reducing flame.
hint: Nickel ammine complexes are typically blue, not green.
solution: Ammine complex of Ni²⁺ is deep blue, not green.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt in Group IV. In Group V, with (NH₄)₂CO₃ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, a white ppt forms that is sparingly soluble in acetic acid, more soluble in hot mineral acid. The cation is:
hint: The solubility pattern of Group V carbonates identifies the specific alkaline earth metal.
solution: SrCO₃ – moderate solubility pattern; CaCO₃ less soluble in acetic acid; BaCO₃ least soluble.

question_text: Which statements on Ba²⁺, Sr²⁺, Ca²⁺ are correct? 1. BaCrO₄ ppt in acetic acid; SrCrO₄ and CaCrO₄ do not, 2. BaSO₄ insoluble in HCl; SrSO₄ and CaSO₄ sparingly soluble, 3. Flame colours: Ba²⁺ apple green, Sr²⁺ crimson, Ca²⁺ brick red, 4. All three form carbonates with (NH₄)₂CO₃.
hint: These are the standard differential properties used to separate and confirm Group V cations.
solution: All are standard separations in Group V.

question_text: A salt solution gives: No flame colour, No ppt in Groups I–V, With Na₂HPO₄ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH: white crystalline ppt. The cation is:
hint: Magnesium is white and is confirmed using the phosphate test in basic medium.
solution: MgNH₄PO₄ is confirmatory ppt for Mg²⁺.

question_text: Which statements on NH₄⁺ are correct? 1. With NaOH on warming → NH₃ gas, 2. NH₃ forms dense white fumes with HCl (NH₄Cl), 3. NH₃ gives brown ppt with Nessler’s reagent, 4. NH₄⁺ is precipitated as NH₄OH in some group.
hint: Ammonium hydroxide is highly soluble and does not precipitate under standard group conditions.
solution: NH₄⁺ is not precipitated as NH₄OH; remains in solution.

question_text: A salt solution, after removing all cations up to Group VI, is treated with NaOH and boiled. No smell, no litmus change, no fumes with HCl rod. This suggests:
hint: Absence of ammonia gas evolution after alkali treatment confirms the absence of ammonium ions.
solution: Absence of NH₃ indicates no NH₄⁺.

question_text: Which anions are colourless and diamagnetic (as stressed in PDF)? 1. CO₃²⁻, 2. NO₃⁻, 3. SO₄²⁻, 4. Cl⁻, Br⁻, I⁻.
hint: All common acidic radicals in the standard syllabus lack partially filled d-orbitals and are thus colorless.
solution: All acid radicals in syllabus are colourless/diamagnetic; salt colour comes from cation.

question_text: A salt liberates colourless gas with vinegar-like odour on addition of dilute H₂SO₄. The gas fumes slightly in cold air. The anion is:
hint: The smell of vinegar is characteristic of Acetic Acid.
solution: Acetic acid vapours have characteristic vinegar smell.

question_text: Confirmatory tests for acetate (CH₃COO⁻): 1. Vinegar smell with H₂SO₄, 2. Ester smell with ethanol + conc. H₂SO₄, 3. No precipitate with AgNO₃ after acidification, 4. Red litmus → blue in solution.
hint: Acetates are weak bases but standard litmus tests are not diagnostic in concentrated salt solutions.
solution: 4 is incorrect; acetate solutions are weakly basic but not strongly litmus-changing.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract is acidified with acetic acid and then treated with BaCl₂ to give a white ppt. This ppt, when mixed with Na₂CO₃ and heated on a charcoal splint in reducing flame, gives Na₂S which turns sodium nitroprusside purple. The original anion is:
hint: The 'Match-stick test' is used specifically for sulfates.
solution: BaSO₄ → BaS upon reduction, then Na₂S gives purple with nitroprusside; this is the match-stick test.

question_text: Which tests are specific for SO₄²⁻? 1. BaCl₂ → white ppt insoluble in HCl, 2. Match-stick test → purple with sodium nitroprusside after reduction, 3. AgNO₃ → white ppt soluble in NH₃, 4. No gas with conc. H₂SO₄.
hint: Silver sulfate is a moderately soluble salt and its reaction with silver nitrate is not diagnostic for sulfate ions.
solution: 3 is for halides/carbonates, not diagnostic for sulphate.

question_text: A salt on treatment with conc. H₂SO₄ + solid K₂Cr₂O₇ gives deep red vapours, which in NaOH solution produce yellow solution giving yellow ppt with Pb(OAc)₂. The anion is:
hint: Deep red vapors of Chromyl Chloride are unique to ionic chlorides.
solution: Chromyl chloride test for chloride: CrO₂Cl₂ vapours → CrO₄²⁻ → PbCrO₄ yellow ppt.

question_text: Interferences in chromyl chloride test for Cl⁻: 1. Br⁻ and I⁻ (oxidised to halogens), 2. NO₂⁻, NO₃⁻, ClO₃⁻, 3. Moisture (forms chromic acid instead), 4. Presence of heavy metal chlorides like AgCl, PbCl₂.
hint: Anything that prevents the formation of CrO₂Cl₂ gas or produces other colored gases interferes.
solution: All four reduce Cl⁻ availability or produce confusing vapours.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract acidified with dil. HNO₃ and treated with AgNO₃ gives pale yellow ppt soluble with difficulty in NH₄OH. Which halide?
hint: The pale yellow color and limited solubility in ammonia point towards the intermediate halide.
solution: AgBr pale yellow, partially soluble in dilute NH₃.

question_text: Correct AgX behaviour: 1. AgCl: white, soluble in dilute NH₃, 2. AgBr: pale yellow, partly soluble in dilute NH₃, soluble in conc. NH₃, 3. AgI: bright yellow, insoluble in dilute NH₃, partly soluble in conc. NH₃, 4. All three soluble in NaCN and Na₂S₂O₃.
hint: Solubility of silver halides decreases from chloride to iodide, but they all form stable soluble complexes with stronger ligands.
solution: Complex formation with CN⁻ and S₂O₃²⁻ dissolves all AgX.

question_text: A salt gives brown gas with conc. H₂SO₄ alone (no solid added). The gas immediately turns starch–KI paper deep blue. Likely anion:
hint: Nitrogen dioxide gas evolved from nitrates is a powerful oxidizer that instantly liberates iodine.
solution: Nitrate with conc. H₂SO₄ → NO₂ (strong oxidant), liberating I₂ from KI instantly.

question_text: For NO₂⁻, reliable tests: 1. Brown fumes of NO₂ with acids, 2. Starch–KI → blue due to I₂ formation, 3. Brown ring with FeSO₄ + conc. H₂SO₄, 4. Decolourisation of acidified KMnO₄ without gas evolution.
hint: The standard brown ring test is specific for Nitrate; Nitrite gives a slightly different reaction that can interfere.
solution: 3 (brown ring) is the nitrate test; nitrite gives its own brown ring only in special variant.

question_text: A salt on strong heating leaves a black residue and emits reddish-brown vapours. The gas further intensifies upon adding copper turnings to its acid solution. The anion is:
hint: The intensification of brown fumes with copper metal identifies Nitrogen Dioxide.
solution: Nitrates decompose, forming NO₂; Cu + HNO₃ → more NO₂.

question_text: Which correctly match “anion – typical silver salt behaviour”? 1. CO₃²⁻ – Ag₂CO₃ white, soluble in HNO₃ and NH₃, 2. SO₄²⁻ – Ag₂SO₄ white, 3. NO₂⁻ – AgNO₂ white crystalline ppt, 4. C₂O₄²⁻ – Ag₂C₂O₄ white ppt.
hint: Silver sulfate is moderately soluble in water and is not typically used as a diagnostic precipitate.
solution: All three (1,3,4) are described; Ag₂SO₄ is sparingly soluble but less used diagnostically.

question_text: A white ppt with AgNO₃ is soluble in HNO₃ and NH₃, and on boiling, the ppt becomes yellowish-brown due to formation of Ag₂O. The anion is:
hint: Thermal decomposition of silver carbonate leads to the formation of silver oxide.
solution: Ag₂CO₃ decomposes to Ag₂O (yellow-brown) + CO₂.

question_text: Which sequences are correct JEE-type differentiations? 1. CO₃²⁻ vs SO₃²⁻ – both milky limewater, but only SO₃²⁻ turns K₂Cr₂O₇ green, 2. S²⁻ vs S₂O₃²⁻ – both give H₂S with strong acids, but only S₂O₃²⁻ gives SO₂ and S initially, 3. Br⁻ vs NO₂⁻ – both brown gases, but NO₂ gives immediate blue starch paper; Br₂ slower, 4. NO₃⁻ vs NO₂⁻ – NO₂⁻ destroyed by urea/ sulphamic acid, then nitrate brown ring test.
hint: These logic patterns are used to distinguish anions that give similar initial results.
solution: All four are emphasized differential strategies.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with Group I–III reagents. In Group IV, no ppt with H₂S in ammoniacal medium. In Group V, no ppt with (NH₄)₂CO₃. In Group VI, no ppt with Na₂HPO₄ (in NH₄OH + NH₄Cl). The cation(s) present must be:
hint: Alkali metals do not form group precipitates in the standard analytical scheme.
solution: Alkali metals are not precipitated in any classical group tests.

question_text: In JEE salt analysis, which cations are purely “spectator” under group reagents (no characteristic ppt)? 1. Na⁺, 2. K⁺, 3. NH₄⁺, 4. Li⁺.
hint: Ammonium is detected at the start, while the alkali metals are only detected through dry tests or very special reagents.
solution: NH₄⁺ is detected at start by NaOH; Na⁺, K⁺, Li⁺ do not precipitate in any group.

question_text: A salt solution gives: Prussian blue with K₄[Fe(CN)₆], No blood-red colour with KSCN. This suggests:
hint: Ferrous iron forms a blue complex with ferrocyanide, while blood-red thiocyanate is specific to ferric iron.
solution: Turnbull’s/Prussian blue with Fe²⁺ + ferricyanide (or ferrocyanide on oxidation); KSCN blood-red is Fe³⁺ only.

question_text: Which are textbook “Prussian blue” systems? 1. Fe³⁺ + K₄[Fe(CN)₆], 2. Fe²⁺ + K₃[Fe(CN)₆], 3. Fe³⁺ + K₃[Fe(CN)₆], 4. Fe²⁺ + K₄[Fe(CN)₆].
hint: Mixed-valence iron cyanide complexes are the origin of these deep blue pigments.
solution: Mixed Fe²⁺/Fe³⁺ with ferri/ferrocyanides give Prussian/Turnbull’s blues.

question_text: A green solution gives green ppt with NaOH that does not dissolve in excess; on exposure to air it darkens. It does not give red ppt with DMG. The cation is:
hint: Air oxidation of green ferrous hydroxide leads to the formation of brown ferric hydroxide.
solution: Fe(OH)₂ green → brown Fe(OH)₃; Ni²⁺ would give DMG ppt; Co²⁺ differently coloured.

question_text: Which sets “anion – acid test gas – confirmatory” are correct? 1. CO₃²⁻ – CO₂ – limewater milky, clears on excess, 2. S²⁻ – H₂S – Pb(OAc)₂ paper black, 3. SO₃²⁻ – SO₂ – K₂Cr₂O₇ paper green, 4. NO₃⁻ – NO₂ – brown ring with FeSO₄.
hint: These represent the standard systematic test sequences for major anions.
solution: All are standard acid-gas test chains.

question_text: A salt gives reddish-brown fumes with conc. H₂SO₄ and MnO₂. Fumes leave no colour in organic layer (CCl₄). The original anion is:
hint: Unlike halogens, the brown vapors of Nitrogen Dioxide are not soluble in non-polar organic solvents.
solution: MnO₂ + nitrate/nitrite + acid → NO₂; NO₂ does not give coloured organic phase like halogens.

question_text: Which statements about iodide tests are correct? 1. Violet vapours with conc. H₂SO₄, 2. Deep-blue starch colour with oxidising agents in acid, 3. Violet organic layer with Cl₂ water + CCl₄, 4. Bright yellow AgI ppt insoluble in dilute NH₃.
hint: Iodide ions show a comprehensive set of redox and precipitation signatures.
solution: All four are classical I⁻ tests.

question_text: A student has mixture containing S²⁻ and SO₃²⁻. On acidification, gas blackens lead acetate paper and also turns K₂Cr₂O₇ paper green. To selectively detect sulphide, one should first:
options: Pass gas through K₂Cr₂O₇ paper, then Pb(OAc)₂ paper
Pre-oxidise SO₃²⁻ to SO₄²⁻ (e.g. with H₂O₂) and then test for S²⁻
answer: Pre-oxidise SO₃²⁻ to SO₄²⁻ (e.g. with H₂O₂) and then test for S²⁻
hint: Sulfites interfere with many sulfur tests by producing sulfur dioxide.
solution: Oxidising sulphite to sulphate removes its SO₂ signal, leaving H₂S detection clearer.

question_text: Which cations are strongly coloured both as salts and in solution? 1. Cu²⁺ – blue, 2. Ni²⁺ – green, 3. Co²⁺ – pink, 4. Cr³⁺ – green.
hint: Transition metals in the d-block have characteristic colors based on d-d electronic transitions.
solution: All are d-block with characteristic colours.

question_text: A salt solution is deep blue. On acidifying with acetic acid and adding K₄[Fe(CN)₆], a chocolate-brown ppt forms. The cation is:
hint: The blue color of the initial solution suggests copper, and the brown ferrocyanide confirms it.
solution: Cu²⁺ gives [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ deep blue and chocolate-brown Cu₂Fe(CN)₆ with ferrocyanide.

question_text: Which pairs “cation – characteristic colour of hydroxide ppt (Group III/IV)” are correct? 1. Fe(OH)₃ – reddish-brown, 2. Cr(OH)₃ – green, 3. Al(OH)₃ – white gelatinous, 4. Zn(OH)₂ – white.
hint: Group III and IV analytical separations rely heavily on these distinctive precipitate colors.
solution: All colours match the group hydroxide table.

question_text: A colourless salt solution gives no ppt with HCl and no ppt with H₂S in acid. With NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, a reddish-brown ppt appears, insoluble in excess. The corresponding aqueous solution is yellow. The cation is:
hint: REDDISH-BROWN precipitate in Group III and a yellow initial solution are specific to this ferric ion.
solution: Group III Fe³⁺ forms yellow solution and brown Fe(OH)₃ with NH₄Cl + NH₄OH.

question_text: An unknown salt solution shows: Prussian blue with K₄[Fe(CN)₆] and Blood-red with KSCN (acidic). Which are consistent?
hint: Both tests (Prussian blue and blood-red thiocyanate) are diagnostic for the same high-oxidation state iron ion.
solution: Both Prussian blue with ferrocyanide and blood-red with SCN⁻ are Fe³⁺ tests; Fe²⁺ is not required.

question_text: A solution gives no ppt with HCl, black ppt with H₂S in acid, soluble in hot HNO₃ giving blue solution. This on reaction with NH₃ (excess) forms a deep blue solution. The cation is:
hint: The blue color of the nitrate solution and the 'Deep Blue' ammine complex confirm Copper.
solution: CuS in Group II, dissolves to Cu²⁺ (blue), then forms [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ deep blue.

question_text: Distinctive confirmatory tests for Cu²⁺: 1. Chocolate-brown ppt with K₄[Fe(CN)₆] in acetic acid, 2. Deep blue [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ in excess NH₃, 3. Bluish-green flame, 4. Yellow ppt with Na₂HPO₄.
hint: Phosphate tests are primarily used for Magnesium in Group VI, not Copper.
solution: Na₂HPO₄ test is for Mg²⁺; 1–3 are copper-specific.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with HCl (cold), partially soluble in hot water. From the hot filtrate, addition of K₂CrO₄ produces yellow ppt and addition of KI also produces yellow ppt. The cation is:
hint: The solubility of the chloride in hot water is the key differentiator for Lead(II) in Group I.
solution: PbCl₂ is sparingly soluble hot; PbCrO₄ and PbI₂ are both yellow.

question_text: A salt solution produces: White ppt with HCl, insoluble on heating; Ppt dissolves in NH₃ and re-forms on acidification; With K₂CrO₄, red ppt. These indicate:
hint: Silver chloride is the only Group I chloride that dissolves in ammonia; Lead chloride does not.
solution: Typical Ag⁺ behaviour; Pb²⁺ would not give soluble chloride in NH₃.

question_text: A salt solution gives pale yellow ppt with AgNO₃ (after HNO₃ acidification), partially soluble in dil. NH₃, and on treatment with Cl₂ water + CCl₄ gives orange-red organic layer. The anion is:
hint: Orange-red color in the organic layer indicates the liberation of free Bromine.
solution: Br⁻: AgBr pale yellow, partly soluble; Br₂ gives orange-red organic layer.

question_text: For I⁻, which observations are standard? 1. Bright yellow AgI ppt, 2. Violet organic layer with Cl₂ water + CCl₄, 3. Violet vapours with conc. H₂SO₄, 4. Immediate deep-blue starch–iodine colour with mild oxidant.
hint: Iodine is easily identified by its violet vapors and its intense blue reaction with starch.
solution: All are typical iodide tests.

question_text: A salt gives no ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium but on adding CaCl₂ + NH₃ + NH₄Cl, a white ppt appears which is insoluble in acetic acid but soluble in mineral acids. The anion is:
hint: Calcium oxalate is a classic precipitate that resists weak acids like acetic acid.
solution: Calcium oxalate CaC₂O₄ is insoluble in acetic acid, soluble in strong acids.

question_text: Oxalate (C₂O₄²⁻) is confirmed by: 1. White CaC₂O₄ ppt (insoluble in AcOH), 2. Decolourisation of acidified KMnO₄ on warming, 3. Evolution of CO + CO₂ with conc. H₂SO₄, 4. Reduction of Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺.
hint: Oxalate is a strong reducing agent and forms an insoluble calcium salt used in separation.
solution: All listed are characteristic oxalate behaviours.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral solution, insoluble in HCl, but the original solid with conc. H₂SO₄ gives no notable gas except slight moisture. The anion is:
hint: Sulphate is the only common anion forming a barium salt that survives strong mineral acid treatment.
solution: Sulphate: BaSO₄ ppt; no characteristic gaseous product with conc. H₂SO₄.

question_text: Features of thiosulphate (S₂O₃²⁻) in qualitative tests: 1. With dilute acids gives SO₂ and S, 2. Decolourises I₂ solution, 3. Gives black ppt with AgNO₃ which turns white, 4. Ultimately yields H₂S that blackens Pb(OAc)₂ paper.
hint: Thiosulphate disproportionates in acid to give a 'milky' turbidity of elemental sulfur.
solution: Standard thiosulphate disproportionation and redox behaviour.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract gives no ppt with BaCl₂, but on adding acidified KMnO₄, pink colour persists in cold, disappearing only on heating with brisk effervescence. The anion is:
hint: Oxalate requires heating to overcome the kinetic barrier to reduce permanganate.
solution: Oxalate requires warming to reduce permanganate; no Ba²⁺ ppt eliminates SO₄²⁻.

question_text: Which gas–anion pairs are correct? 1. H₂S – S²⁻, 2. SO₂ – SO₃²⁻, 3. NO₂ – NO₂⁻ or NO₃⁻ (with conc. H₂SO₄), 4. CH₃COOH vapours – CH₃COO⁻.
hint: Strong acid releases characteristic volatile acidic gases from these radicals.
solution: All reflect standard acidification behaviours.

question_text: On adding dilute H₂SO₄ to a salt, colourless gas evolves that turns limewater milky, and on further passage, the milkiness disappears. The anion is:
hint: The disappearance of milkiness is due to the formation of soluble bicarbonate.
solution: CO₂ produces CaCO₃ then Ca(HCO₃)₂ on prolonged passage, clearing turbidity.

question_text: Features that distinguish SO₃²⁻ from CO₃²⁻: 1. Both turn limewater milky, 2. Only SO₂ reduces acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ green, 3. Only SO₂ decolourises acidified KMnO₄ in cold, 4. CO₂ is odourless; SO₂ pungent.
hint: While both form insoluble calcium salts, only the sulfite is a strong reducing agent.
solution: 1 is common behaviour, not distinguishing; 2–4 differentiate.

question_text: A salt on strong heating gives reddish-brown vapours that intensify with copper turnings. These vapours slowly colour starch–KI paper deep blue. The original anion is:
hint: Copper metal is used to reduce NO₃⁻ to NO₂, producing dense brown fumes.
solution: Nitrate + conc. H₂SO₄ + Cu → NO₂, a strong oxidant liberating I₂.

question_text: Conditions critical for a clean nitrate brown ring test: 1. FeSO₄ solution must be freshly prepared, 2. Acid must be added down the side, 3. Solution must not be heated or shaken, 4. Nitrite, Br⁻, I⁻ should be removed/absent.
hint: Any disturbance or conflicting redox reaction will destroy the delicate brown nitrosyl layer.
solution: All are explicitly stressed to avoid false results.

question_text: During copper iodometric titration, the brown solution of Cu²⁺ + KI becomes colourless with a white ppt. This is due to:
options: Formation of CuI and I⁻ (after thiosulphate)
hint: The white precipitate remains once the iodine has been consumed by the titrant.
solution: Cu²⁺ + 4I⁻ → 2CuI(s) + I₂; I₂ then titrated by S₂O₃²⁻ to I⁻ leaving CuI white.

question_text: An unknown solution gives: Deep blue with excess NH₃, Chocolate-brown ppt with K₄[Fe(CN)₆], Bluish-green flame. This confirms:
hint: These are the three most iconic tests for the presence of Copper(II).
solution: All three are copper signatures; Ni²⁺ is separate.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂ and no ppt with AgNO₃. With NaHCO₃ + Br₂ water, on heating, a black ppt appears. The cation is:
hint: Nickel(II) is oxidized by hypobromite to black Nickel(III) oxide/hydroxide.
solution: Ni²⁺ gives NiCO₃ → NiO black in the hypobromite-type reaction noted.

question_text: Which of the following are correct colour associations? 1. BaCrO₄ – yellow, 2. SrSO₄ – white, 3. CaC₂O₄ – white, 4. PbCrO₄ – yellow.
hint: Group V and related heavy metal salts have standard colors in the qualitative scheme.
solution: All match standard colours.

question_text: A dry test tube heating of a salt leaves a white sublimate on cooler parts of tube. Possible ions include:
hint: Mercury chlorides and ammonium salts are famous for subliming when heated.
solution: Sublimable salts like HgCl₂, Hg₂Cl₂, NH₄Cl; mercury chlorides are typical white sublimates.

question_text: Ammonium salts on strong heating with NaOH give a gas that: 1. Turns moist red litmus blue, 2. Forms white fumes with HCl, 3. Produces brown ppt with Nessler’s reagent, 4. Blackens lead acetate paper.
hint: Lead acetate paper is specifically used to detect the rotten-egg gas H₂S.
solution: All 1–3 are NH₃ tests; 4 is H₂S.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with group reagents up to Group III. With NH₄Cl + NH₄OH + H₂S, a black ppt forms, insoluble in dilute HCl and in acetic acid, but dissolves in aqua regia to a green solution that does not form red ppt with DMG. The cation is:
hint: Nickel would have given a red precipitate with Dimethylglyoxime (DMG); Cobalt does not.
solution: CoS is Group IV, black, gives Co²⁺ solution; no DMG red ppt (Ni-specific).

question_text: A Group IV mixture after H₂S treatment in NH₄Cl–NH₄OH gives a black ppt of CoS + NiS. After dissolving and evaporation, adding NH₄OH + CH₃COOH + KNO₂ gives a yellow ppt. This sequence confirms:
hint: The yellow ppt is potassium cobaltinitrite; the filtrate then contains the nickel ion.
solution: Standard Co³⁺ nitrito complex (yellow) and Ni-DMG red ppt.

question_text: A salt solution, when treated with cobalt nitrate + Na₂CO₃ on charcoal and strongly heated, produces a blue mass. This indicates:
hint: Thenard's blue is the specific dry test result for aluminum ions.
solution: Cobalt nitrate test for Al³⁺ → cobalt aluminate (Thenard’s blue).

question_text: Which ions give no characteristic flame colour but clear wet-test signatures? 1. Zn²⁺, 2. Mg²⁺, 3. Fe³⁺, 4. Al³⁺.
hint: Most d-block metals (other than Copper) and aluminum/magnesium do not have diagnostic flames.
solution: All lack distinct flame colours; identified by ppt/complex tests.

question_text: A salt solution gives brown-red ppt with NaOH, insoluble in excess, which turns green on adding excess Na₂CO₃ and heating gently, then becomes black with NaOCl. The cation is:
hint: Nickel(II) transitions through green hydroxide to higher black oxides.
solution: Ni(OH)₂ green; black NiO/Ni(OH)₃ under oxidative conditions; colour pattern matches nickel.

question_text: Key distinguishing wet tests between Ca²⁺ and Ba²⁺: 1. BaCrO₄ ppt in acetic acid; CaCrO₄ not, 2. BaSO₄ insoluble in HCl; CaSO₄ slightly soluble, 3. CaC₂O₄ ppt with (NH₄)₂C₂O₄ even in acetic acid, 4. Ba²⁺ gives apple-green flame; Ca²⁺ brick-red.
hint: Distinction relies on the much lower solubility of Barium salts compared to Calcium.
solution: All are used to separate and identify Ca²⁺ and Ba²⁺.

question_text: A salt solution gives crimson red flame. In Group V, it precipitates as SrCO₃, soluble in acetic acid to give solution forming SrSO₄ with (NH₄)₂SO₄. The cation is:
hint: Crimson flame is the definitive flame test signature for Strontium.
solution: Sr²⁺: crimson flame, SrSO₄ ppt.

question_text: Which observations unambiguously suggest Ba²⁺ in a mixture of alkaline earths? 1. Yellow ppt BaCrO₄ insoluble in acetic acid, 2. Apple-green flame, 3. BaSO₄ insoluble in HCl, 4. No reaction with (NH₄)₂C₂O₄.
hint: Barium does react with oxalate, but the test is less specific than chromate.
solution: BaC₂O₄ is more soluble; main distinctive tests are chromate, sulphate, flame.

question_text: A salt gives no ppt with HCl. With NaOH it produces a blue ppt insoluble in excess. The ppt turns black on heating. Flame test is bluish-green. The cation is:
hint: Bluish-green flame and the thermal decomposition of blue hydroxide to black oxide point to this metal.
solution: Cu(OH)₂ blue → CuO black, copper flame colour.

question_text: Which ions are paramagnetic and give coloured solutions? 1. Cu²⁺, 2. Ni²⁺, 3. Co²⁺, 4. Fe³⁺.
hint: Incomplete d-shells result in unpaired electrons (paramagnetism) and d-d electronic transitions (color).
solution: All d-block with unpaired electrons, coloured and paramagnetic.

question_text: A solution of Fe²⁺ is mixed with a solution of NO₂⁻ in acidic medium. Over time, Fe²⁺ is converted to Fe³⁺ and NO₂⁻ converted to:
hint: Nitrite can act as an oxidizing agent, particularly in its transition towards the nitrate state.
solution: Nitrite can act as oxidant, giving nitrate while Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺.

question_text: Which statements about Fe²⁺ vs Fe³⁺ in qualitative analysis are correct? 1. Fe²⁺ gives Turnbull’s blue with ferricyanide, 2. Fe³⁺ gives Prussian blue with ferrocyanide, 3. Fe²⁺ is easily oxidised to Fe³⁺ by air, 4. Fe³⁺ gives blood-red colour with KSCN.
hint: Both ions show distinctive mixed-valence complexes and coordination colors.
solution: All are standard iron redox/complex facts.

question_text: A salt solution is green due to Fe²⁺. On boiling with dil. HNO₃, colour becomes yellow-brown. On adding K₄[Fe(CN)₆], a Prussian blue ppt appears. This sequence shows:
options: Oxidation of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ by HNO₃
answer: Oxidation of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ by HNO₃
hint: Nitric acid is the standard oxidizing agent used to ensure Iron is in the ferric form before Group III precipitation.
solution: Green Fe²⁺ → yellow-brown Fe³⁺; Prussian blue with ferrocyanide.

question_text: Sources of false brown fumes in anion analysis (other than nitrate/nitrite): 1. Br₂ vapours, 2. I₂ vapours mixed with air, 3. NO₂ from nitrite impurities, 4. Organic matter charring.
hint: Many chemical reactions and impurities can mimic the visual appearance of nitrogen dioxide fumes.
solution: All can contribute confusing brownish fumes/colours.

question_text: While detecting nitrite, addition of acid to nitrite + KI + starch paper gives immediate deep-blue colour. The blue is due to:
hint: The blue color in starch-iodide tests always results from the liberation of free Iodine.
solution: NO₂ oxidises I⁻ to I₂, which forms blue complex with starch.

question_text: Select pairs correctly matching cation with most important confirmatory test: 1. Ni²⁺ – DMG red ppt, 2. Mg²⁺ – Na₂HPO₄, 3. Ba²⁺ – K₂CrO₄, 4. K⁺ – yellow ppt with cobaltinitrite.
hint: These reagents are the primary methods for final cation identification in standard schemes.
solution: All four are classical confirmatory tests.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with HCl or H₂S (acid). With NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, no ppt. With H₂S in ammoniacal medium, a pink ppt appears, soluble in dil. HCl, giving a colourless solution that on oxidation with PbO₂/HNO₃ becomes purple. The cation is:
hint: The pink sulfide and the final purple permanganate oxidation state are definitive signatures.
solution: MnS buff/pink; Mn²⁺ → permanganate (purple).

question_text: Which statements about Mn²⁺ are correct? 1. MnS buff/pink in Group IV, 2. Mn(OH)₂ white, turning brown in air, 3. With PbO₂ + HNO₃, gives permanganic acid, 4. With NaBiO₃ + HNO₃, gives permanganate.
hint: Manganese has a variety of oxidation states and characteristic sulfide and hydroxide colors.
solution: All are standard Mn²⁺ reactions.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium that is soluble in HCl. The solid salt with conc. H₂SO₄ evolves a colourless gas with rotten-egg smell. The anion is:
hint: The rotten-egg smell identifies Hydrogen Sulfide, liberated from sulfide salts.
solution: Barium Sulfide dissolves in acid; conc. H₂SO₄ + sulphide → H₂S rotten-egg gas.

question_text: Which anions ultimately yield H₂S upon strong acidification? 1. S²⁻, 2. S₂O₃²⁻, 3. SO₃²⁻, 4. SO₄²⁻.
hint: Sulfide and thiosulfate are reduced forms of sulfur capable of producing H₂S.
solution: Sulphide and thiosulphate can give H₂S; sulphite gives SO₂.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt in all cation groups but when boiled with NaOH, no gas is evolved. Flame is colourless. With Na₂HPO₄ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, no ppt appears. The cation(s) most likely present:
hint: Alkali metals do not form group precipitates and can be difficult to detect if flame colors are weak.
solution: Alkali metals show neither group ppts nor Mg-phosphate test.

question_text: In the sodium carbonate extract method, fusion with Na₂CO₃ converts: 1. Insoluble sulphates → Na₂SO₄, 2. Insoluble chlorides → NaCl, 3. Insoluble phosphates → Na₃PO₄, 4. Insoluble silicates → Na₂SiO₃.
hint: The process is designed to 'unlock' anions from insoluble metal salts by creating soluble sodium equivalents.
solution: All listed are targets of carbonate fusion.

question_text: A salt mixture is known to contain Cu²⁺ and Zn²⁺ only. After Group II H₂S precipitation and separation of CuS, Zn²⁺ remains in filtrate. To confirm Zn²⁺, one should:
options: Precipitate ZnS in Group IV, dissolve in HCl, then use K₄[Fe(CN)₆]
answer: Precipitate ZnS in Group IV, dissolve in HCl, then use K₄[Fe(CN)₆]
hint: Confirmatory zinc testing uses the white sulfide and subsequent formation of white ferrocyanide.
solution: Standard Zn²⁺: ZnS (white) then ferrocyanide white ppt.

question_text: Typical interferences in cation analysis introduced by certain anions: 1. PO₄³⁻ forming insoluble phosphates, 2. C₂O₄²⁻ forming insoluble oxalates, 3. Tartrate forming complexes, 4. NO₃⁻ forming coloured complexes.
hint: Nitrate is generally a spectator ion and does not interfere with the systematic separation of cation groups.
solution: Nitrate is usually spectator; others are genuine interfering radicals.

question_text: A salt produces blue borax bead in oxidising flame, greenish bead in reducing flame, and gives green solution in water. The cation is:
hint: The 'amethyst' or blue-violet oxidizing bead and green aqueous color are characteristic of Nickel.
solution: Nickel bead is violet/blue oxidising, brownish-grey reducing; Ni²⁺ gives amethyst/greenish beads and green solution.

question_text: Essential precautions in qualitative salt analysis practical: 1. Use minimum volume of reagents, 2. Avoid shaking/boiling during layered tests, 3. Remove H₂S by boiling before Group III, 4. Always test anions using sodium carbonate extract (except CO₃²⁻/HCO₃⁻).
hint: Success in salt analysis depends on strict adherence to systematic steps and careful handling of reagents.
solution: All four are standard pillars of salt analysis.

question_text: Which radicals can give brown fumes with conc. H₂SO₄ on heating a solid salt? 1. NO₃⁻, 2. NO₂⁻, 3. Br⁻, 4. I⁻
hint: While Bromine is reddish-brown, Nitrogen Dioxide is the primary source of 'brown' fumes in standard acid tests.
solution: Nitrates and nitrites produce NO₂ brown fumes; Br₂ gives reddish brown but via HBr oxidation, not pure NO₂.

question_text: A salt on heating with Na₂CO₃ + KNO₃ (fusion mixture) followed by extraction with water gives a yellow solution, which with Pb(OAc)₂ gives a yellow ppt. The original cation is:
hint: This oxidative fusion process converts a trivalent transition metal into a hexavalent yellow oxo-anion.
solution: Oxidative fusion of Cr³⁺ yields yellow chromate; PbCrO₄ is yellow.

question_text: NH₄Cl is added before precipitating Group III hydroxides because it: 1. Buffers the solution, 2. Suppresses ionisation of NH₄OH, 3. Prevents precipitation of Mg(OH)₂, 4. Prevents precipitation of BaCO₃
hint: The goal is to maintain a specific hydroxide concentration using the common-ion effect.
solution: NH₄Cl lowers [OH⁻] just enough to precipitate Fe³⁺, Al³⁺, Cr³⁺, but not Mg²⁺; Ba²⁺ is not in this group.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with HCl, but with H₂S in acid medium a canary yellow ppt forms, insoluble in yellow ammonium sulphide. The cation is:
hint: Only one yellow sulfide in Group II is insoluble in yellow ammonium sulfide.
solution: CdS is bright yellow, belongs to Group IIA, and is insoluble in yellow (NH₄)₂S.

question_text: Which tests confirm NH₄⁺? 1. Pungent gas with NaOH turning red litmus blue, 2. Dense white fumes with HCl gas, 3. Brown ppt with Nessler’s reagent, 4. Blackening of Pb(OAc)₂ paper
hint: Lead acetate paper is specifically used to detect Hydrogen Sulfide gas.
solution: 4 is for H₂S; 1–3 are standard NH₄⁺ tests.

question_text: A salt solution gives deep blue colour with excess NH₃, and a chocolate brown ppt with K₄[Fe(CN)₆] on acidification. This identifies:
hint: Copper is known for forming the intense blue tetraammine complex.
solution: [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ is deep blue; Cu²⁺ + ferrocyanide gives brown Cu₂Fe(CN)₆.

question_text: Which are zero-group cations in the classical scheme? 1. NH₄⁺, 2. Na⁺, 3. K⁺, 4. Mg²⁺
hint: These cations are not precipitated by any of the standard Group I-V reagents.
solution: NH₄⁺, Na⁺, K⁺ are not precipitated by any group reagent; Mg²⁺ is Group VI.

question_text: A salt solution gives red lake with alizarin on ammoniation and also gives blue bead in borax bead test. The cation is:
hint: While aluminum gives an alizarin lake, cobalt gives a specific lake color and a very stable blue bead.
solution: Co²⁺ gives blue borax bead and red lake with Alizarin.

question_text: Correct statements about Group II separation: 1. Group II sulphides precipitate in acidic H₂S due to very low Ksp, 2. HCl is used so that Ba²⁺, Sr²⁺, Ca²⁺ sulphates do not precipitate, 3. Group IIB sulphides dissolve in yellow (NH₄)₂S, 4. PbS is classified in Group IIB
hint: Lead sulfide belongs to the 'Insoluble in yellow ammonium sulfide' subgroup.
solution: PbS is in Group IIA, insoluble in yellow ammonium sulphide.

question_text: A solid salt on heating in a dry test tube gives violet vapours that turn starch paper blue-black. The anion is:
hint: Violet vapor is a definitive indicator of free Iodine.
solution: Iodides with conc. H₂SO₄ give violet I₂ fumes; iodine colours starch deep blue.

question_text: Which anions commonly reduce acidified KMnO₄? 1. C₂O₄²⁻, 2. S₂O₃²⁻, 3. SO₃²⁻, 4. Cl⁻
hint: Potassium Permanganate is an oxidizer that reacts with common reducing acid radicals.
solution: Oxalate, thiosulphate, sulphite are classic reducers; Cl⁻ generally not under mild conditions.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with AgNO₃ that is insoluble in NH₃ but dissolves in Na₂S₂O₃ solution. The anion is:
hint: This anion forms the most insoluble silver halide among the common group.
solution: AgI is insoluble in NH₃ but soluble in thiosulphate.

question_text: Distinction between CO₃²⁻ and SO₃²⁻ by gases evolved with dilute acid: 1. CO₂ is colourless, odourless, turns limewater milky, 2. SO₂ is colourless, pungent, reduces acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ to green, 3. Both give same effect on lead acetate paper, 4. Only SO₂ decolourises KMnO₄ in cold
hint: CO₂ has no effect on lead acetate paper, while SO₂ may exhibit slight sensitivity.
solution: CO₂ does not blacken Pb(OAc)₂ or reduce KMnO₄; SO₂ does.

question_text: A colourless salt solution gives buff ppt with H₂S in alkaline medium, soluble in dil. HCl, and with PbO₂/HNO₃ the solution becomes purple. The cation is:
hint: The 'buff' (light pink) color of the sulfide and the purple permanganate result are specific to this ion.
solution: MnS buff; Mn²⁺ oxidised to permanganate (purple) by PbO₂/HNO₃.

question_text: Which are amphoteric hydroxides in this scheme? 1. Al(OH)₃, 2. Zn(OH)₂, 3. Cr(OH)₃, 4. Pb(OH)₂
hint: These hydroxides dissolve in excess strong alkali to form soluble complex anions.
solution: All four hydroxides dissolve in excess strong alkali to give complex anions.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt up to Group III. Passing H₂S in presence of NH₄OH + NH₄Cl gives a white ppt soluble in dil. HCl. The cation is:
hint: Zinc forms the only truly white sulfide in the standard analytical Groups.
solution: ZnS is Group IV, white, acid-soluble; Ba²⁺, Ca²⁺ are Group V.

question_text: Which distinguish Ba²⁺, Sr²⁺, Ca²⁺? 1. K₂CrO₄ in AcOH medium, 2. (NH₄)₂SO₄, 3. (NH₄)₂C₂O₄, 4. Flame test
hint: These reagents follow the sequential solubility order of the Group V metals.
solution: BaCrO₄ in AcOH, SrSO₄, CaC₂O₄, and flame colours separate them.

question_text: A salt solution gives intense blood-red colour with KSCN in acidic medium. On adding NaF, the colour disappears. The cation is:
hint: Thiocyanate forms a complex with Iron(III) that is destabilized by fluoride ions.
solution: Fe³⁺ + SCN⁻ → Fe(SCN)₃ (blood-red) bleached by F⁻ due to complexation.

question_text: Correct behaviour of AgX with reagents: 1. AgCl soluble in dilute NH₃, 2. AgBr sparingly soluble in dilute NH₃, soluble in conc. NH₃, 3. AgI insoluble even in conc. NH₃, 4. All dissolve in Na₂S₂O₃
hint: The prompt identifies the standard triad taught in JEE curricula.
solution: 2,3,4 is the taught triad; AgCl is actually fully soluble in dilute NH3, but the set sequence is used to distinguish.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract gives no ppt with AgNO₃ even after acidifying, but with FeSO₄ + conc. H₂SO₄ (brown-ring test), a brown ring forms. The anion is:
hint: Brown ring formation is the classic confirmation for nitrates.
solution: Brown-ring is characteristic of nitrate; nitrite interferes but also gives other tests.

question_text: Which statements about Na₂CO₃ extract (SCE) are true? 1. Prepared by boiling salt with Na₂CO₃ and water, 2. Converts insoluble salts into soluble Na⁺ salts, 3. Not required for soluble halides, 4. Necessary for sulphate in BaSO₄
hint: Barium sulfate is highly resistant and often requires fusion rather than just boiling for SCE preparation.
solution: BaSO₄ is hardly decomposed by Na₂CO₃ under mild lab conditions; special fusion may be needed.

question_text: A salt solution is green. With NH₄OH + NH₄Cl, a green gelatinous ppt appears soluble in excess NaOH to a green solution; fusion with Na₂CO₃ + KNO₃ yields chromate. The cation is:
hint: Green gelatinous hydroxide in Group III belongs to the Chromium ion.
solution: Cr(OH)₃ green, amphoteric; fusion gives chromate.

question_text: Which pairs of anion–test are correctly matched? 1. CO₃²⁻ – limewater test, 2. S²⁻ – sodium nitroprusside purple, 3. NO₂⁻ – starch-KI paper blue-black, 4. SO₄²⁻ – BaCl₂ white ppt insoluble in HCl
hint: These are the four standard confirmatory tests for common anions.
solution: All four are textbook confirmatory tests.

question_text: A colourless solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium, insoluble in HCl. No gas is evolved with dilute acids. The anion is:
hint: Insolubility of the Barium salt in mineral acid is unique to the sulfate ion.
solution: BaSO₄ is acid-insoluble; sulphate gives no gas with acids.

question_text: Which observations suggest presence of thiosulphate (S₂O₃²⁻)? 1. On acidification: SO₂ + S (milky), 2. I₂ solution decolourised, 3. With AgNO₃: white ppt slowly turns black, 4. With Pb(OAc)₂: black PbS ppt
hint: Direct formation of a black lead sulfide precipitate with acetate is the test for sulfide, not thiosulfate.
solution: 4 is for sulphide; Ag₂S₂O₃ darkens via decomposition.

question_text: A colourless salt solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium, insoluble in HCl. The original solid with conc. H₂SO₄ gives no characteristic gas. The anion is:
hint: Sulfate is the only common anion that forms a barium precipitate without a volatile acid product.
solution: BaSO₄ is white and acid-insoluble; sulphate gives no diagnostic gas with conc. H₂SO₄.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with HCl. Sulphide ppt with H₂S in acid that is yellow and insoluble in yellow (NH₄)₂S. This suggests presence of: 1. Cd²⁺, 2. Hg²⁺, 3. Cu²⁺, 4. Bi³⁺
hint: Other Group II cations like Mercury, Copper, and Bismuth form black sulfides.
solution: In Group IIA, CdS is yellow; HgS, CuS, Bi₂S₃ are black.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt up to Group III. With NH₄Cl + NH₄OH + H₂S, a buff/light-pink ppt appears, soluble in warm dilute HCl. Oxidation with PbO₂/HNO₃ yields a purple solution. The cation is:
hint: The purple solution is Permanganic acid, formed by the oxidation of Manganese.
solution: MnS buff/pink; Mn²⁺ oxidised to permanganate (purple) with PbO₂/HNO₃.

question_text: Which are correct about Zn²⁺ and Mg²⁺ separation? 1. Zn²⁺ precipitates as ZnS in Group IV; Mg²⁺ stays in solution, 2. Mg²⁺ is confirmed as MgNH₄PO₄ with Na₂HPO₄ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, 3. Zn²⁺ is confirmed by white ppt with K₄[Fe(CN)₆], 4. Both are precipitated together in Group VI
hint: Zinc is removed as a sulfide earlier in the systematic procedure than Magnesium.
solution: Zn²⁺ is Group IV; Mg²⁺ is Group VI; ferrocyanide and MgNH₄PO₄ tests confirm them.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract on acidification with dil. HCl produces a colourless gas with pungent smell like burning sulphur and turns acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ solution green. The anion is:
hint: The 'burning sulphur' smell and reduction of dichromate are the signature tests for sulfite.
solution: SO₃²⁻ gives SO₂, which is pungent and reduces dichromate to Cr³⁺.

question_text: Correct about H₂S use: 1. Acidified H₂S precipitates Group II cations as sulphides, 2. H₂S in ammoniacal medium precipitates Group IV cations, 3. Sulphide salts + acid evolve H₂S that blackens Pb(OAc)₂ paper, 4. Na₂S/(NH₄)₂S can fully replace H₂S in acidic
hint: Replacement of H₂S gas by liquid sulfide solutions is generally only done in basic groups.
solution: Group II uses dissolved H₂S; alkaline sulphide solutions are mainly used as yellow ammonium sulphide.

question_text: A salt solution is blue. On adding excess NH₄OH, it turns intensely deep blue. Acidify, then add K₄[Fe(CN)₆]; a chocolate-brown ppt appears. The cation is:
hint: The chocolate-brown ferrocyanide is the most definitive wet test for copper.
solution: [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ is deep blue; Cu²⁺ with ferrocyanide gives brown Cu₂Fe(CN)₆.

question_text: Which are correct confirmatory chains? 1. Pb²⁺: PbS → PbSO₄ → PbCrO₄ / PbI₂, 2. Ni²⁺: NiS → Ni²⁺ → Ni(DMG)₂ (red), 3. Co²⁺: CoS → Co²⁺ → K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] (yellow), 4. Ba²⁺: BaCO₃ → BaCrO₄ (in acetic acid)
hint: These sequences represent the standard identification paths in systematic analysis.
solution: All four appear as standard chains in notes.

question_text: A green salt solution, on treatment with KNO₂ + CH₃COOH + excess K⁺, gives no ppt. On adding DMG in basic medium, a rose-red ppt forms. The cation is:
hint: Cobalt would have given a yellow precipitate with nitrite, but only Nickel gives a red complex with DMG.
solution: Ni²⁺ gives Ni(DMG)₂ red; Co²⁺ would have given K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] yellow.

question_text: Distinguishing Br⁻ and I⁻ using Cl₂ water + CCl₄: 1. Add Cl₂ water and shake with CCl₄, 2. Br⁻: orange-red organic layer, 3. I⁻: violet organic layer, 4. Excess Cl₂ decolourises Br₂ but not I₂ quickly
hint: Halogen displacement and solubility in non-polar solvents allow for clear visual differentiation.
solution: Standard halogen displacement and organic-layer colours.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract gives white ppt with AgNO₃ after acidifying with HNO₃. The ppt dissolves in dilute NH₃ and reappears on acidification. Chromyl chloride test is negative. The anion is:
hint: While Silver Chloride also behaves this way, the negative chromyl chloride test rules it out.
solution: Ag₂CO₃ white, NH₃-soluble; chromyl chloride negative rules out Cl⁻.

question_text: Canonical carbonate (CO₃²⁻) behaviour: 1. Effervescence with dil. acids, CO₂, 2. Limewater milky, clearing on excess CO₂, 3. White ppt with MgSO₄ in cold for normal carbonate, 4. Bicarbonate gives MgSO₄ ppt only on heating
hint: This differential testing with Magnesium is used to distinguish normal carbonates from bicarbonates.
solution: All four appear in carbonate tests.

question_text: In a nitrate test, a student shakes and warms the FeSO₄–H₂SO₄ layer. No brown ring forms; solution turns yellow. Explanation:
hint: The brown nitrosyl-iron complex is thermally unstable and sensitive to mechanical agitation.
solution: Heating/shaking let NOx escape and destroy Fe(H₂O)₅NO²⁺ complex.

question_text: For a good brown ring: 1. Use freshly prepared FeSO₄, 2. Cool solutions, 3. Add conc. H₂SO₄ down the tube side, 4. Do not mix or warm after layering
hint: Careful layering and temperature control are necessary to preserve the delicate interface complex.
solution: All are emphasised in nitrate test section.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract gives white crystalline ppt with AgNO₃ (after acidification) and no ppt with BaCl₂. The anion is:
hint: Nitrate does not form any standard precipitate with Silver ions.
solution: AgNO₂ forms a white crystalline ppt; absence of Ba²⁺ ppt excludes SO₄²⁻.

question_text: Nitrite (NO₂⁻) shows: 1. NO₂ fumes with dilute acid, 2. Immediate blue starch-KI paper, 3. Decolourises acidified KMnO₄ without gas, 4. The standard nitrate brown-ring test unchanged
hint: Nitrite interferes with the standard nitrate test and produces different results.
solution: 4 is not the classic step; nitrite interferes with nitrate test.

question_text: A salt with BaCl₂ gives white ppt soluble in AcOH but not in conc. HCl. With conc. H₂SO₄ + K₂Cr₂O₇, no chromyl chloride distillate. The anion is:
hint: Barium sulfate is famously insoluble in mineral acids, unlike the barium salt of this reducing radical.
solution: Oxalate forms BaC₂O₄: acetic-insoluble, mineral-acid soluble; chromyl chloride negative.

question_text: Reagents and detected species: 1. Nessler’s – NH₃/NH₄⁺, 2. Sodium nitroprusside – S²⁻, 3. DMG – Ni²⁺, 4. K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] – K⁺/Co³⁺ complex
hint: These are specific confirmatory tests widely used in systematic analysis.
solution: All four are explicitly used in the theory PDFs.

question_text: A salt solution gives Group V carbonate ppt, which: Is white, insoluble in AcOH; Forms SrSO₄ with (NH₄)₂SO₄; Does not form BaCrO₄ in acetic medium. The cation is:
hint: Strontium carbonate is less soluble in acetic acid than barium carbonate but is identified by its sulfate.
solution: SrCO₃ → SrSO₄; chromate selectivity pattern points to Strontium.

question_text: Group IV ppt (black) dissolved in aqua regia, then: NH₄OH + CH₃COOH + KNO₂ → yellow ppt; No red DMG ppt attempted. This supports:
hint: The yellow cobaltinitrite precipitate specifically confirms Cobalt.
solution: Only Co²⁺ is directly confirmed; Ni²⁺, Mn²⁺ need extra tests.

question_text: A salt gives bluish-green flame, black ppt with H₂S in acid (CuS), soluble in warm HNO₃ to a blue solution. The cation is:
hint: Standard Group II identification for a commonly occurring transition metal.
solution: Classic copper behaviour: blue solution, black sulfide, blue-green flame.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract shows: With AgNO₃ + HNO₃: white ppt soluble in NH₃; With BaCl₂: no ppt. Possible anions are: 1. CO₃²⁻, 2. Cl⁻, 3. NO₃⁻
hint: Silver carbonate and Silver chloride are both white and ammonia-soluble.
solution: Ag₂CO₃ and AgCl are NH₃-soluble; nitrate gives no ppt; BaCl₂ excludes SO₄²⁻.

question_text: A solid salt heated in a dry test tube gives a crackling sound and brown fumes. The anion is most likely:
hint: Decrepitation (crackling) and nitrogen dioxide evolution are characteristic of heavy metal nitrates.
solution: Lead nitrate decomposes with crackling and NO₂ fumes.

question_text: Group reagents whose selectivity relies on Ksp + common-ion: 1. HCl (Cl⁻) – Group I, 2. H₂S + HCl (S²⁻) – Group II, 3. NH₄OH + NH₄Cl (OH⁻) – Group III, 4. H₂S + NH₄OH + NH₄Cl (S²⁻) – Group IV
hint: Selective precipitation depends on controlling the concentration of the precipitating anion.
solution: All are textbook Ksp-based separations.

question_text: An unknown salt: Does not decolourise KMnO₄ in cold, but does on heating; Gives no gas with dil. H₂SO₄; Gives no BaCl₂ ppt; With CaCl₂ + NH₃ + NH₄Cl: white ppt soluble in acids and AcOH. The anion is:
hint: The requirement for heat and the solubility of the calcium salt distinguish this from sulfite.
solution: Oxalate reduces permanganate only on warming; CaC₂O₄ fits solubility pattern.

question_text: A salt solution gives a green ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl (Group III), which dissolves in excess NaOH to a green solution. On fusion with KNO₃ + Na₂CO₃, the melt gives yellow chromate extract. The cation is:
hint: Green gelatinous hydroxide in Group III that undergoes oxidative fusion to yellow chromate is specific to this metal.
solution: Cr(OH)₃ is green; on fusion with KNO₃/Na₂CO₃ it converts to yellow chromate (Na₂CrO₄).

question_text: To confirm Al³⁺ from Group III ppt: 1. White gelatinous ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl, 2. Soluble in excess NaOH (aluminate), 3. Re-ppt with NH₄Cl on boiling, 4. Blue mass with cobalt nitrate on charcoal.
hint: Aluminum is identified by its amphoteric hydroxide and the characteristic Thenard's blue dry test.
solution: All four are standard confirmatory tests for Aluminum (Al³⁺).

question_text: A salt solution gives: No ppt with HCl or H₂S in acid; Reddish-brown ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl; Ppt dissolves in HCl to a yellow solution. The cation is:
hint: Ferric salts are yellow in solution and form a rust-colored insoluble hydroxide in Group III.
solution: Fe³⁺ is in Group III; reddish-brown hydroxide and yellow chloride solution are characteristic.

question_text: Correct matches of flame colour – cation: 1. Crimson – Li⁺, Sr²⁺, 2. Yellow – Na⁺, 3. Lilac – K⁺, 4. Apple green – Ba²⁺.
hint: Refer to the standard Bunsen flame emission table for s-block elements.
solution: All matches align with the standard flame-colour table.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with HCl, but with H₂S in acid a black ppt forms that is soluble in hot KCN solution. The filtrate, on passing H₂S, gives no ppt. The cation is:
hint: Copper sulfide dissolves in cyanide to form a stable soluble complex, distinguishing it from cadmium.
solution: CuS dissolves in KCN to form [Cu(CN)₄]³⁻; CdS does not, and no re-ppt occurs with H₂S.

question_text: Recognising S²⁻: 1. Rotten-egg gas (H₂S) with acids, 2. Black PbS on lead acetate paper, 3. Purple colour with sodium nitroprusside (in alkaline medium), 4. Black Ag₂S with AgNO₃.
hint: Sulphide is identified by its smell and highly insoluble black metal salts.
solution: All four are standard tests for the sulphide ion (S²⁻).

question_text: A salt solution produces chocolate-brown ppt with K₄[Fe(CN)₆] only when acidified with acetic acid. The same solution gives blue-green flame. The cation is:
hint: The chocolate-brown ferrocyanide and blue-green flame are specific to this transition metal.
solution: Cu²⁺ + ferrocyanide → Cu₂Fe(CN)₆ (brown); flame color confirms copper.

question_text: Which describe NO₂ vs Br₂ fumes correctly? 1. Both are brown, 2. NO₂ is a stronger oxidant, gives instant starch–KI blue, 3. Br₂ slower to give blue with starch–KI, 4. Br₂ imparts brown colour to organic solvents; NO₂ does not.
hint: Differentiation relies on oxidation rate and solubility in non-polar organic phases.
solution: All four are standard ways to distinguish NO₂ from Br₂ fumes.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium, which is insoluble in HCl. With dilute acid, the solid salt gives SO₂ (burning sulphur smell). The anion is:
hint: Sulphite forms BaSO₃ which should be soluble in HCl; if the question implies a sequence of tests, the SO₂ gas points to sulphite.
solution: Sulphite ion gives SO₂ with acids and forms a white barium salt.

question_text: Which help differentiate SO₄²⁻, SO₃²⁻, S²⁻? 1. BaCl₂ ppt behaviour (HCl solubility), 2. Nature of gas with dilute acid, 3. Lead acetate paper, 4. Effect on acidified K₂Cr₂O₇/KMnO₄.
hint: Sulphate is inert to redox, while sulphite and sulphide are powerful reducers with distinctive smells.
solution: All these tests are used in the systematic anion flowchart to distinguish sulphur-containing ions.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt up to Group IV. In Group V, white ppt with (NH₄)₂CO₃ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH that is insoluble in AcOH and gives yellow BaCrO₄ ppt from its solution. The cation is:
hint: Among Group V, only Barium forms a yellow chromate precipitate in an acetic acid medium.
solution: BaCO₃ and BaCrO₄ are insoluble in AcOH, unlike the Sr/Ca counterparts.

question_text: Correct interfering radicals for cation analysis: 1. PO₄³⁻, 2. C₂O₄²⁻, 3. Tartrate, citrate, 4. NO₃⁻.
hint: Interfering anions are those that form insoluble salts with Group IV-VI metals in the basic Group III medium.
solution: Phosphate, oxalate, and complexing organic anions interfere; nitrate usually does not.

question_text: A salt solution gives no precipitate in any cation group, but on addition of NaOH and warming, a gas with pungent smell is evolved that turns red litmus blue and gives brown ppt with Nessler’s reagent. The cation is:
hint: Liberation of ammonia gas is the standard test for the ammonium ion.
solution: NH₄⁺ → NH₃ with NaOH; Nessler’s test positive confirms ammonium.

question_text: Reactions valid for Nessler’s test: 1. K₂HgI₄ + NH₃ + KOH → brown HgO·HgNH₂I ppt, 2. Test is sensitive for NH₃ at ppm level, 3. Other basic gases (e.g., amines) may interfere, 4. NH₄⁺ must be first converted to NH₃ with alkali.
hint: The test uses an alkaline potassium tetraiodomercurate(II) solution to detect ammonia.
solution: All these points appear in the Nessler test chemistry section.

question_text: A salt shows green borax bead in oxidising flame and bottle-green in reducing flame. Its aqueous solution is yellowish. The cation is:
hint: Transition metals are identified by their characteristic metaborate bead colors in different flame types.
solution: Chromium gives green beads in both flames and yellowish-green solutions.

question_text: Which are coloured but diamagnetic complexes in your notes? 1. [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺, 2. [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻, 3. [Co(NO₂)₆]³⁻, 4. [Ni(DMG)₂].
hint: Diamagnetism occurs when all electrons are paired, often in low-spin octahedral complexes like ferrocyanide.
solution: [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻ and [Co(NO₂)₆]³⁻ are low-spin d⁶ with spin-only zero; Cu complex is paramagnetic.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with AgNO₃. With FeSO₄ and conc. H₂SO₄ (added along tube wall), a blue ring appears instead of brown ring when diphenylamine is present. The anion is:
hint: Strong oxidizers give a blue reaction with diphenylamine in acidic conditions.
solution: Diphenylamine–H₂SO₄ test gives blue ring for strong oxidisers like dichromate.

question_text: Particulars about sodium carbonate extract (SCE): 1. Prepared by boiling salt with Na₂CO₃ and water, 2. Brings anions of insoluble salts into solution as Na⁺ salts, 3. Not needed for CO₃²⁻ / HCO₃⁻ detection, 4. Must be filtered before use.
hint: SCE preparation is the first step for systematic anion testing of insoluble samples.
solution: All stated points are standard steps in the SCE procedure.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂, but with CaCl₂ + NH₃ + NH₄Cl, a white ppt forms that dissolves in AcOH and mineral acids. On heating with acidified KMnO₄, the pink colour decolourises with effervescence. The anion is:
hint: The decolourisation of KMnO₄ on heating with gas evolution identifies the oxalate radical.
solution: Oxalate reduces KMnO₄; CaC₂O₄ fits the described solubility profile.

question_text: Which cations form amphoteric hydroxides in your scheme? 1. Al³⁺, 2. Zn²⁺, 3. Cr³⁺, 4. Pb²⁺.
hint: Amphoteric hydroxides dissolve in excess alkali to form complex oxy-anions.
solution: All four hydroxides dissolve in excess strong alkali to give complex anions.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with AgNO₃, partially soluble in dilute NH₃ and fully soluble in conc. NH₃. The anion is:
hint: Silver bromide has limited solubility in dilute ammonia compared to silver chloride.
solution: AgBr is pale yellow (often looks off-white) and partly soluble in dilute NH₃.

question_text: Thiosulphate S₂O₃²⁻ shows: 1. Decolourises iodine solution, 2. On acidification, gives SO₂ + S, 3. With AgNO₃, gives white ppt that darkens, 4. Acts as complexant for AgX in photography.
hint: Thiosulphate chemistry involves sulfur disproportionation and powerful complexation with silver.
solution: All features appear in the thiosulphate ion section.

question_text: A salt solution produces no ppt up to Group IV. With (NH₄)₂CO₃ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, a white ppt forms that: Is partially soluble in AcOH; Gives brick-red flame. The cation is:
hint: The brick-red flame color is the definitive signature for Calcium.
solution: CaCO₃ precipitates in Group V; Ca²⁺ gives brick-red flame; solubility is intermediate.

question_text: Which about phosphate (PO₄³⁻) are correct? 1. Yellow ammonium phosphomolybdate ppt, 2. Yellow Ag₃PO₄ with AgNO₃, 3. Interferes by precipitating Grp III metals, 4. Removed by precipitating as MgNH₄PO₄.
hint: Phosphates are major interfering anions requiring removal or specific precipitation steps.
solution: All steps appear in the phosphate interference/analysis sections.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂. With NaOH, a white ppt forms on boiling that redissolves on adding NH₄Cl. With Na₂HPO₄ in presence of NH₄OH/NH₄Cl, a white crystalline ppt appears slowly. The cation is:
hint: Magnesium is identified by its slow-forming crystalline phosphate precipitate in basic buffer.
solution: Mg(OH)₂ behaviour and MgNH₄PO₄ confirmatory test identified magnesium.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂, but on adding CaCl₂ + NH₄Cl + NH₃, a white ppt forms soluble in AcOH and mineral acids. On warming with acidified KMnO₄, the pink colour discharges with effervescence. The anion is:
hint: Decolourisation of permanganate with gas evolution on warming is the signature for oxalate.
solution: CaC₂O₄ behaves this way; oxalate reduces KMnO₄ on heating.

question_text: Correct about phosphate (PO₄³⁻) detection: 1. Yellow ppt of ammonium phosphomolybdate, 2. Forms yellow ppt of Ag₃PO₄ with AgNO₃, 3. Interferes by precipitating Group III cations, 4. Removed by precipitating as MgNH₄PO₄.
hint: This matches the standard properties of the phosphate ion in qualitative analysis.
solution: All steps appear in the interference and phosphate sections.

question_text: A salt on heating with conc. H₂SO₄ + solid K₂Cr₂O₇ gives deep red vapours, which in NaOH yield a yellow solution giving yellow ppt with Pb(OAc)₂. The original anion is:
hint: This is the 'Chromyl Chloride' test, highly specific for chloride ions.
solution: Chromyl chloride test is specific for ionic chlorides; PbCrO₄ is the final yellow ppt.

question_text: Which radicals do not give chromyl chloride test? 1. Covalent chlorides like HgCl₂, 2. Bromides and iodides, 3. Nitrates and nitrites, 4. Cl⁻ in NaCl.
hint: The test requires a sufficiently ionic chloride to react with dichromate in acid.
solution: Only ionic chlorides like NaCl/KCl work; others interfere or are negative.

question_text: A salt solution gives pale pink flame and a buff ppt with H₂S in alkaline medium, soluble in dil. HCl. The cation is:
hint: The 'buff' (light pink) color of the sulfide precipitate is the signature for Manganese.
solution: Mn²⁺ gives pale pink salts and characteristic buff MnS in Group IV.

question_text: To confirm Co²⁺ from Group IV: 1. Dissolve sulphide in aqua regia to get CoCl₂ (blue, turns pink in water), 2. Add NH₄Cl + NH₄OH + KNO₂ → yellow K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] ppt, 3. Use thiocyanate + amyl alcohol to get blue layer, 4. Use DMG in basic medium to form red ppt.
hint: The red DMG precipitate is specific for Nickel, not Cobalt.
solution: 4 is for Ni²⁺; 1–3 are standard Co²⁺ tests.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂, but on passing H₂S in acid medium, a black ppt forms insoluble in hot KCN. The cation is:
hint: Mercury(II) sulfide is exceptionally insoluble and does not dissolve in cyanide, unlike copper sulfide.
solution: HgS is black and very insoluble even in hot KCN; CuS dissolves.

question_text: Which statements describe SO₃²⁻ vs S₂O₃²⁻ on acidification? 1. SO₃²⁻ → SO₂ only, 2. S₂O₃²⁻ → SO₂ + S, 3. Both can reduce acidified KMnO₄, 4. Only S₂O₃²⁻ shows milky suspension of sulphur.
hint: Thiosulphate produces elemental sulfur (milky suspension) while sulphite only produces gaseous sulfur dioxide.
solution: SO₃²⁻ gives no sulphur; both reduce oxidants but milky sulphur is unique to thiosulphate.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with AgNO₃ after acidifying, which slowly turns black on standing. The anion is:
hint: The slow conversion of white silver thiosulphate to black silver sulphide is a characteristic reaction.
solution: Ag₂S₂O₃ decomposes to black Ag₂S on standing.

question_text: Which help confirm S²⁻ specifically (not SO₃²⁻ or S₂O₃²⁻)? 1. Rotten-egg smell gas with dilute acid, 2. Blackening of lead acetate paper, 3. Formation of CdS yellow with Cd²⁺ paper test, 4. Purple colour with sodium nitroprusside (alkaline).
hint: All these tests rely on the presence of the free sulphide ion or H₂S gas.
solution: All four are listed under sulphide ion reactions.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl + (NH₄)₂CO₃ that is insoluble in AcOH and gives apple-green flame. The cation is:
hint: Apple-green is the unique Bunsen flame color for Barium.
solution: BaCO₃ is AcOH-insoluble; Ba²⁺ gives apple-green flame.

question_text: Which statements on Group V are correct? 1. Precipitated as carbonates with (NH₄)₂CO₃, 2. Precipitation done in alkaline/neutral solution to avoid MgCO₃, 3. BaCO₃, SrCO₃, CaCO₃ are initially obtained, 4. Mg²⁺ remains in filtrate for Group VI.
hint: Group V involves the separation of the heavy alkaline earth metals from magnesium.
solution: All are correctly described in the cation-group scheme.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt in any group reagent, but on adding disodium hydrogen phosphate + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, a white crystalline ppt slowly appears. The cation is:
hint: Magnesium remains in the final filtrate and is confirmed using the phosphate test.
solution: Mg²⁺ is confirmed as MgNH₄PO₄ in Group VI.

question_text: Which radicals are commonly removed before cation analysis as interfering radicals? 1. PO₄³⁻, 2. C₂O₄²⁻, 3. Tartrate/citrate, 4. NO₃⁻.
hint: Interfering radicals are those that would precipitate Group IV-VI metals prematurely in Group III.
solution: Nitrate is generally non-interfering; others are major interferences.

question_text: A salt solution is blue. With NaOH, a blue ppt forms, turning black on heating. With NH₄OH, a deep blue solution forms. The cation is:
hint: The deep blue solution (tetraamminecopper(II)) and the formation of black CuO identify copper.
solution: Cu(OH)₂ blue → CuO black; [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ deep blue.

question_text: Which flame colours are correct? 1. Na⁺ – golden yellow, 2. K⁺ – lilac/violet, 3. Sr²⁺ – crimson red, 4. Ba²⁺ – apple green.
hint: These are the standard flame emissions for the respective metal cations.
solution: All match the provided flame-colour table.

question_text: A salt solution gives yellow ppt with AgNO₃, sparingly soluble in dil. NH₃ but dissolving in conc. NH₃. The anion is:
hint: Silver bromide is pale yellow and has intermediate solubility in ammonia.
solution: AgBr pale yellow, partially soluble in dilute, soluble in conc. NH₃.

question_text: Which species give Prussian-blue type precipitates with K₄[Fe(CN)₆]/K₃[Fe(CN)₆]? 1. Fe³⁺ + K₄[Fe(CN)₆], 2. Fe²⁺ + K₃[Fe(CN)₆], 3. Cu²⁺ + K₄[Fe(CN)₆], 4. Zn²⁺ + K₄[Fe(CN)₆].
hint: Prussian blue and Turnbull's blue are mixed-valence iron cyanide complexes.
solution: 1 and 2 give Prussian/Turnbull’s blue; Cu²⁺ gives chocolate-brown, Zn²⁺ white.

question_text: A colourless salt solution does not decolourise KMnO₄ in cold, but on heating it does, with evolution of CO₂. With CaCl₂ + NH₃ + NH₄Cl, a white ppt forms soluble in mineral acids and AcOH. The anion is:
hint: Oxalate requires heating to reduce permanganate and forms an acetic-insoluble calcium salt.
solution: Oxalate reduces KMnO₄ on warming; CaC₂O₄ matches the solubility pattern.

question_text: Which radical pairs both show effervescence with dil. H₂SO₄ but give different secondary tests? 1. CO₃²⁻ and HCO₃⁻, 2. CO₃²⁻ and SO₃²⁻, 3. NO₂⁻ and S₂O₃²⁻, 4. Cl⁻ and Br⁻.
hint: Class A anions produce volatile gases with dilute acid that are then distinguished by redox or lime water tests.
solution: All 1–3 evolve characteristic gases with effervescence.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt up to Group IV. With (NH₄)₂CO₃ + NH₄Cl + NH₄OH, a white ppt forms partially soluble in AcOH and showing crimson flame. The cation is:
hint: The crimson flame test is the standard confirmation for Strontium.
solution: SrCO₃ moderately soluble in AcOH; Sr²⁺ gives crimson flame.

question_text: Which complexes are coloured and diamagnetic as given in the notes? 1. [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻, 2. [Co(NO₂)₆]³⁻, 3. [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺, 4. [Ni(DMG)₂].
hint: Diamagnetism in colored complexes often occurs in low-spin d⁶ configurations.
solution: Both 1 and 2 are low-spin and cited as spin-only zero; Cu complex is paramagnetic.

question_text: During nitrate test, a student adds FeSO₄ after H₂SO₄ and shakes strongly; only yellow solution forms, no ring. The reason is:
hint: The brown ring is thermally unstable and easily destroyed by mixing/shaking.
solution: Shaking/warming lets NO escape and destroys Fe(H₂O)₅NO²⁺ brown-ring complex.

question_text: To make brown-ring test reliable: 1. Use freshly prepared FeSO₄, 2. Cool both solutions, 3. Add conc. H₂SO₄ down the wall, 4. Avoid shaking after layering.
hint: Precise handling and temperature control are required to preserve the delicate nitrosyl complex.
solution: All four precautions are emphasised for a successful nitrate test.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with AgNO₃, but with BaCl₂ a white ppt forms, insoluble in HCl. With NaOH, a white ppt appears only at high concentration. The anion is:
hint: Sulphate is the primary anion that forms a barium salt insoluble in strong mineral acid.
solution: BaSO₄ is acid-insoluble; acetate and nitrate do not ppt with Ba²⁺ in neutral solution.

question_text: Which sets show gas + flame behaviour correctly? 1. CO – burns with blue flame, 2. H₂ – burns with pale blue flame, 3. CH₄ – burns with blue, sooty flame in air, 4. NH₃ – burns with yellow flame forming N₂.
hint: Carbon monoxide and hydrogen are common flammable gases evolved in some salt reactions.
solution: 3 is generally non-sooty in good oxygen; 4 is not a standard lab test here.

question_text: A salt solution gives black ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl + H₂S (Group IV) that is insoluble in dil. HCl but on oxidation with NaOBr/NaOH gives green solution. The cation is:
hint: Nickel(II) is the ion that forms a green solution upon oxidation with hypobromite.
solution: NiS is black; Ni²⁺ forms green Ni(OH)₂/NiO(OH) with hypohalite oxidation.

question_text: To distinguish Ni²⁺ from Co²⁺ in Group IV: 1. Ni²⁺ forms red Ni(DMG)₂ ppt, 2. Co²⁺ forms yellow K₃[Co(NO₂)₆], 3. Ni²⁺ gives brown solution with SCN⁻/amyl alcohol, 4. Co²⁺ gives blue layer with SCN⁻/amyl alcohol.
hint: Cobalt forms a blue complex with thiocyanate in organic solvents; Nickel does not.
solution: 3 is not listed; 1, 2, 4 are standard Ni/Co differentiation tests.

question_text: A sodium carbonate extract gives pungent gas with HCl, turning acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ solution green but no blackening of lead acetate paper. The anion is:
hint: The 'pungent' gas that reduces dichromate but does not react with lead acetate is sulfur dioxide.
solution: Sulphite → SO₂; reduces dichromate, but does not form black PbS.

question_text: Correct statements about nitrite (NO₂⁻): 1. Gives NO₂ fumes with dilute acid, 2. Immediately blue starch–KI paper, 3. Decolourises acidified KMnO₄ without gas, 4. Gives pale blue liquid (HNO₂) with conc. H₂SO₄ in cold.
hint: Nitrite reduction of permanganate usually evolves gas as NO/NO₂ are produced.
solution: KMnO₄ is decolourised, but NO/NO₂ gases evolve; description 3 is incomplete.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with HCl, black ppt with H₂S in acid (CuS), which dissolves in hot dilute HNO₃ to give blue solution. With KI, the solution becomes brown, then colourless with Na₂S₂O₃. The cation is:
hint: These iodometric reactions (liberation of I₂ and its subsequent titration) are standard for copper.
solution: Classic Cu²⁺ iodometric reactions are described.

question_text: Which tests are used for Al³⁺? 1. White gelatinous ppt with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl, 2. Soluble in excess NaOH (aluminate), 3. Blue bead with cobalt nitrate on ignition, 4. Blood-red thiocyanate complex.
hint: Thiocyanate is used for the detection of iron(III), not aluminum.
solution: 4 is for Fe³⁺; 1–3 are Al³⁺ features.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with AgNO₃ after acidification, which is curdy white, dissolves in NH₃ and reappears with HNO₃. Chromyl chloride test positive. The anion is:
hint: The 'curdy white' silver salt and the specific chromyl chloride test confirm chloride.
solution: AgCl and positive chromyl chloride test confirm chloride.

question_text: Which anions definitely require SCE (sodium carbonate extract) for reliable detection when in insoluble salts? 1. SO₄²⁻ in BaSO₄, 2. S²⁻ in ZnS, 3. PO₄³⁻ in Ca₃(PO₄)₂, 4. C₂O₄²⁻ in CaC₂O₄.
hint: SCE is necessary to liberate oxo-anions from highly insoluble minerals.
solution: S²⁻ is generally tested on original salt with acids; insoluble phosphates/oxalates converted via SCE.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with H₂S in acid or with NH₄OH in presence of NH₄Cl. But on treating with NH₄OH + NH₄Cl + H₂S, a white ppt forms; flame test shows no characteristic colour. The cation is:
hint: Zinc sulfide is the unique white sulfide precipitate found in Group IV.
solution: Zn²⁺ (Group IV) gives white ZnS; Mg²⁺ is in Group VI.

question_text: Which observation chains are valid confirmatory paths? 1. Pb²⁺: PbS → PbSO₄ → PbCrO₄ / PbI₂, 2. Cu²⁺: CuS → Cu²⁺ → [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ deep blue, 3. Ni²⁺: NiS → Ni²⁺ → Ni(DMG)₂ red, 4. Co²⁺: CoS → Co²⁺ → K₃[Co(NO₂)₆] yellow.
hint: These sequences follow the standard systematic separation and confirmation logic.
solution: All four paths align with the systematic scheme.

question_text: A colourless solution produces no ppt with BaCl₂, but on treatment with KMnO₄ + dil. H₂SO₄ in cold, pink colour disappears without gas. Starch–KI paper turns blue. The anion is:
hint: Nitrite is a strong enough oxidizer to liberate iodine and reduces permanganate instantly in the cold.
solution: Nitrite reduces KMnO₄ and liberates iodine from I⁻, creating the blue starch–iodine color.

question_text: Which about nitrate vs nitrite are correct? 1. Both give brown-ring test, 2. Nitrite first must be removed with sulphamic acid for nitrate test, 3. Nitrite on its own can give brown ring with FeSO₄/H₂SO₄, 4. Nitrate gives NO₂ directly with dilute acid.
hint: Nitrate is much more stable than nitrite and requires concentrated acid to produce brown fumes.
solution: Nitrate needs strong acid; nitrite interference and sulphamic-acid removal are standard noted points.

question_text: A salt solution gives green ppt with NaOH, insoluble in excess, which on oxidation with H₂O₂ in alkali turns brown, and borax bead gives bottle-green in oxidising, blue-green in reducing flame. The cation is:
hint: The green hydroxide and bottle-green borax bead identify chromium.
solution: Cr(OH)₃ is green; Cr borax bead is characteristically bottle-green.

question_text: Which observations point to Fe²⁺ (not Fe³⁺)? 1. Fresh solution decolourises acidified KMnO₄, 2. Turns blood-red with KSCN, 3. Gives blue ppt with K₃[Fe(CN)₆], 4. Slowly oxidises in air to Fe³⁺ brown solution.
hint: Blood-red thiocyanate is the specific test for the ferric (Fe³⁺) state.
solution: Blood-red thiocyanate is Fe³⁺; Fe²⁺ gives blue with ferricyanide and acts as a reducer.

question_text: A salt solution gives white ppt with BaCl₂ in neutral medium, soluble in HCl. Passing Cl₂ water and shaking with CCl₄ gives orange organic layer. The anion is:
hint: The orange layer indicates the presence of liberated Bromine.
solution: Bromide is oxidised to Br₂ (orange in CCl₄); BaBr₂ remains soluble in the BaCl₂ test.

question_text: Identify Br⁻ vs I⁻ using Cl₂ water + CCl₄: 1. Br₂ gives orange organic layer, 2. I₂ gives violet organic layer, 3. Excess Cl₂ decolourises Br₂ colour, 4. Excess Cl₂ slowly decolourises I₂ colour.
hint: Halogen displacement and over-oxidation with excess chlorine help differentiate these halides.
solution: All four are mentioned in systematic halide differentiation.

question_text: A salt solution gives pale yellow ppt with AgNO₃ after acidifying, sparingly soluble in NH₄OH and sparingly soluble in hot water. On cooling, needle-like crystals appear. The anion is:
hint: Silver bromide is pale yellow and has specific solubility characteristics used for identification.
solution: AgBr pale yellow, partly NH₃-soluble; PbBr₂ (if present from cation side) would also give needle crystals.

question_text: Which behaviours of carbonate/hydrogen carbonate are correct? 1. Both effervesce with dilute acids, 2. Only normal carbonate gives ppt with MgSO₄ in cold, 3. Bicarbonate needs heating with MgSO₄ to give ppt, 4. Phenolphthalein pink with CO₃²⁻, colourless with HCO₃⁻.
hint: Magnesium sulfate and indicators are used to distinguish between simple and acid carbonates.
solution: All four are standard observations noted for the carbonate system.

question_text: A salt solution gives no ppt with BaCl₂. With AgNO₃ (after acidifying), a white crystalline ppt appears, and starch–KI paper with acid becomes blue. The anion is:
hint: Nitrite forms a crystalline silver salt and is a strong enough oxidant to liberate iodine.
solution: AgNO₂ forms white crystalline ppt; nitrite liberates iodine (blue with starch-KI).
